metadata.title: Investigation on strength and microstructure characteristics of nano-MgO admixed with cemented soft soil

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
Investigation on strength and microstructure characteristics of nano-MgO admixed with cemented soft soil
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2019.01.221 0950-0618/ 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: yaokai@u.nus.edu (K. Yao), wellswang@usx.edu.cn (W. Wang),
lina@usx.edu.cn (N. Li), lxwang@usx.edu.cn (L. Wang).
Kai Yao b, Wei Wang a,⇑, Na Li a, Chen Zhang a, Linxia Wang c a School of Civil Engineering, Shaoxing University, Shaoxing, Zhejiang 312000, PR China bDepartment of Civil and Environmental Engineering, National University of Singapore, 1 Engineering Drive 2, Singapore 117576, Singapore c School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaoxing University, Shaoxing, Zhejiang 312000, PR China
h i g h l i g h t s
Evaluation of the effectiveness of nano-MgO in the strength properties of cemented soft soil. Effect of sulfuric acid attack was taken into consideration. Microstructure of nano-MgO-cement-soil mixture was investigated.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 29 September 2018 Received in revised form 14 December 2018 Accepted 28 January 2019
Keywords: Nano-MgO Cement Soft soil Sulfuric acid attack Unconfined compressive strength Microstructure
a b s t r a c t
The effectiveness of nano-MgO in strength properties and microstructure characteristics of cement stabilized soft soil were analyzed in this study. Sulfuric acid attack was also taken into account, and the effects nano-MgO content and sulfuric acid concentration were mainly addressed. Based on a series of unconfined compression tests, it shows that nano-MgO content plays a significant role in the strength properties of the stabilized soil. For the cement content of 13%, the optimum nano-MgO content is 15‰ considering both with and without sulphate attack condition. The addition of nano-MgO not only improves the unconfined compressive strength (UCS) of the cement stabilized soil, but also tends to increase its ductility. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) reveals that the addition of nano-MgO improves the microstructure of the stabilized soil, while overuse of nano-MgOmay generate cracks inside of the structure. For the effect of sulfuric acid concentration, specimens under higher concentration solution will have lower strength and stiffness. Finally, the mechanism of sulfuric acid attack on cemented soil was revealed to be outside structure loss caused by sulfuric acid erosion and inside structure distortion caused by ettringite generation.
2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Soil stabilization has become a significantly popular technique in recent decades, owing to the high demand for infrastructures in areas with the poor quality ground or limited space (e.g. [1]). Cement is a commonly adopted binder for stabilizing soft soils in ground improvement for soft ground or land reclamation for dredged fills (e.g. [2–4] and Liu et al. [5–7,9]). However, the use of cement as a stabilizer will have an adverse effect on the environment. One is that the manufacture of cement causes 5–7% of global carbon dioxide emissions (e.g. [10,11]). Another is that cemented soil usually appears as high alkaline, disserving the ground water
quality and vegetation (e.g. [12,9]). Besides of this, cement stabilized soil (like subgrade soil) in coastal areas is always subjected to wetting by sulfate-containing seawater, where there is a high possibility of sulfate-induced heave (e.g. [13–15]). In order to control or lessen the usage of cement, it is highly necessary to discover an admixture that can improve the mechanical and durability performance of cement stabilized soil (e.g. [16,17]). Nowadays, Magnesia (MgO) has been chosen as a green and low carbon stabilizer for soft soil, since reactive MgO is produced at a lower temperature with less fuel consumption and CO2 emissions compared to Portland cement (e.g. [18–20,21]). With the astonishing development of nano-technology, nano-structured binder is paid extensive attention, due to that the main hydrate C–S–H gel of cement is an also natural nanostructured material (e.g. [22–25]). In terms of nano-MgO, Ye et al. [23] adopted it as the expansive agent for cement and concrete, and it was found in their study that
the maximum content of nano-MgO added in ordinary Portland cement is up to 8% for soundness. Song et al. [26] investigated the mechanical and electrochemical properties of cement paste containing nano-MgO, and it was revealed that the flexural and compressive strength of the cement paste gradually increases with nano-MgO contents (from 0 wt% to 9 wt%). And it was stated that the mechanism of nano-MgO enhancement is mainly contributed by a certain expansion the production of hydrated product magnesium hydroxide (i.e. the conversion of MgO to Mg(OH)2). In another word, the hydration of nano-MgO will be well thorough due to its high specific surface, and the expansion of nano-MgO enhances filling effect in capillary pores [27]. Recently, Wang et al. [28] investigated the effectiveness of nano-MgO as an additive for cement stabilized soil, and it was revealed that the addition of nano-MgO demonstrates positive contribution in the shear strength of cement stabilized soil. But the cement content and nano-MgO content was a certain value (i.e. 5% and 10‰ for cement content and nano-MgO content, respectively), and the effect of sulfuric acid attack was not taken into account. In this study, nanoMgO was used as an admixture for cemented soft soil, and various nano-MgO contents were considered in a series of unconfined compression tests and micro-structure analysis. Sulfuric acid attack with various sulfuric acid concentrations was also carried out on the specimens of cement stabilized soil to investigate the efficiency of nano-MgO in the durability of cement stabilized soil.
2. Laboratory investigation
2.1. Materials
Soft soil used in this study was collected from coastal areas in Zhejiang Province, P.R. China. As the homogeneity of soil is a key factor for the consistency of experimental results, the soft soil was firstly mixed with water to be a slurry
state, and then screened by a sieve with 2 mm diameter to remove the coarse particles (like shells and small rocks). The screened soil is with specific gravity, liquid limit and plastic limit of 2.6, 43.5% and 30%, respectively. For the soft soil stabilization, Type 1 ordinary Portland cement (OPC) was adopted as the binder while nano-MgO was used as an admixture. OPC was obtained from Shangyu Conch Cement Co., Ltd., P.R. China, while nano-MgO (physical parameters listed in Table 1) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (Shanghai) Trading Co., Ltd., P.R. China. The sulfuric acid solution (composition of H₂SO₄; molar weight of 98.078; density of 1.8305 g/cm3) was also used to simulate severe condition, which was purchased from Zhejiang Zhongxing Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., P.R. China.
2.2. Sample preparation, curing, and testing
The definition of mix ratio of cement-admixed soil follows that proposed by [29,30] and [7,8], which is characterized by the mass ratio of soil solid (s): dry cement solid (c): water (w). Cement content (Aw) is the mass ratio of cement to dry soil solid (i.e. mc/ms), while total water content (Cw) is the mass ratio of water to the sum of dry soil and cement solids (i.e. mw=ðms þmcÞ). Nano-MgO content (an) is defined as the mass of nano-MgO over the mass of the cement-soil mixture (i.e. mn=ðms þmc þmwÞ). In terms of the sample preparation, the current water content of the soft soils is measured one day before specimen preparation. Then the water needed for the designed mix ratio (see Table 2) could be easily obtained. The soil, water, cement, and nano-MgO were homogeneously mixed in a Hobart mixer for around 10 min. The admixture was then transferred into lubricated cylindrical polyvinyl chloride (PVC) molds with 39.1 mm in diameter and 80 mm in height. To ensure the uniformity of the specimen, the mixture was poured into the mold by three layers. And a stainless bar was adopted to compact each layer for 30times. After this, the specimens were cured in deionized water for the first 24 h. Thereafter, they were demolded and put in an incubator with a specific temperature of 22 and humidity of 95%. Once the specimens were cured in the incubator for a certain period, they were put into sulfuric acid solution for a certain erosion period to simulate the sulfuric acid attack condition. Unconfined compression test (UCT) was then conducted following the procedures prescribed by ISO/TS 17892 [31], with a strain rate of 1 mm per minute, to measure the strength of the treated soil. Table 2 summarizes the test programs in this study. For the scenarios listed in Table 2, UC-1 is aimed to investigate the effect of cement content without any sulfuric acid attack, while UC-2 is to investigate the effect of nano-MgO con-
tent. UC-3 and UC-4 are to evaluate the influence of nano-MgO content and sulfuric acid concentration, respectively, on the performance of cemented soil under sulfuric acid attack.

sections.heading: 3.1. Effect of cement content
sections.text:
Fig. 1a shows the shear stress-strain curves from UCT for the cemented soil with various cement content. It can be seen that
there is an initial slow growth stage for the shear stress. This is due to the fitting process for the initial compression stage due to the gap between the specimen and the top cap of the apparatus. Thereafter, the shear stress increases rapidly with a shear strain within a certain strain level, and then the shear stress drops after it reaches the peak value (failure stress). The failure stress is also termed as unconfined compressive strength (UCS). It can be seen that the value of UCS differs due to various cement content. It also exhibits that the post-failure stress of cemented soil with higher cement content (i.e. 13% and 17%) drops much
more rapidly than those with lower cement content (i.e. 7% and 10%), which reveals that higher cement content leads to a more brittle material. As illustrated in Fig. 1b, the UCS of the cemented soil will increase with cement content. It can be identified that UCS increases almost linearly when cement content grows from 7% to 13%, while its increment rate slows down from cement content of 13% to 17%. This is the reason why cement content of 13% was used for the other test scenarios UC-2, UC-3 and UC-4 (see Table 2).

sections.heading: 3.2. Effect of nano-MgO content
sections.text:
Fig. 2 illustrate the stress-strain curves for specimens with various nano-MgO contents, under both normal (Fig. 2a) and sulfuric acid attack condition (Fig. 2b). As shown in Fig. 2a, the stress rises along with the strain until the peak value (i.e. UCS) at failure strain, and then it drops with the strain. It indicates that the addition of nano-MgO will not have a significant influence on the stressstrain characteristics (i.e. the phenomena of stress-strain curves)
of the stabilized soil. But it also reveals clearly that the UCS value varies for a specimen with different nano-MgO content, meaning that the nano-MgO content has an influence on the strength of the stabilized soil. Except for the amplitude of the stress-strain curve (i.e. the value of UCS), the failure strain also varies with the nano-MgO content. It can be seen that the failure strain tends to increase with increasing nano-MgO content. This implies that the addition of nano-MgO increases the ductility of the stabilized soil. For the pre-yielding part, it can be seen that higher nanoMgO content (i.e. 15‰ and 20‰) leads to steeper stress-strain curves, meaning higher stiffness of the stabilized soil. For the post-yielding (strain softening) part, all the curves drop rapidly due to the strain increment, despite of the nano-MgO content. For the nano-MgO and cement stabilized soil under sulfuric acid attack shown in Fig. 2b, it can be seen that the stress-strain curves tend to be gentler compared with those without sulfuric acid attack in Fig. 2b, and the failure strain for each case will be greatly increased due to the sulfuric acid attack. This indicates that the specimens become softer after the sulfuric acid attack. Moreover, the UCS of each case also shows an obvious drop after the sulfuric acid attack. This implies that the sulfuric acid attack will significantly lower both the strength and stiffness of the stabilized soil.
Fig. 3 shows the variation of UCS with nano-MgO content. It can be seen that the UCS of specimens under sulfuric acid attack tends to be much lower than those without sulfuric acid attack. The worst scenario is the specimen without nano-MgO, and it nearly lost all the strength after being attacked by a sulfuric acid solution. Although sulfuric acid attack will also lower the strength properties for nano-MgO and cement stabilized soil, the specimens are still with a few hundred kPa’s strength. In another word, the addition of nano-MgO could increase the durability performance of the stabilized soil. What’s more, the nano-MgO content also has an effect on the durability performance of the stabilized soil. For both scenario shown in Fig. 3a and b, a specimen with the nano-MgO content of 15‰ demonstrates the most promising UCS value. Moreover, it reveals from Fig. 3b that nano-MgO content of 15‰ also brings about maximum UCS ratio (the ratio of UCS under sulfuric acid attack over that under normal condition). Thus, the optimum nano-MgO content is 15‰ for cemented stabilized soil with 13% cement content.
For the microstructure shown in Fig. 4, the soil particles can be clearly identified in all the images. Fig. 4a illustrates among the big soil particle, there exist two main types of particles (i.e. globular and acicular). This is because when the specimen is submerged inside the sulfuric acid solution, chemical reactions with SO42 ion will generate some ettringite (acicular particles). These particles are randomly distributed with obvious large pores inside the whole structure. Generally, the microstructure of stabilized soil without nano-MgO is still not close-knit. With the addition of nano-MgO of 5‰, the acicular particles tend to form agglomerates around the soil particles. Meanwhile, the overall structure tends to be condensed due to the generation of Mg(OH)2 (Fig. 4b).When the nano-MgO content is 10‰, it can be seen from Fig. 4c that the small particles continue to combine together to form larger agglomerates. The system tends to become more compacted as the size of the pores is remarkably reduced. This is due to more Mg(OH)2 are generated, leading to more expansion. Once the agglomeration reaches a certain level (nano-MgO content of 15‰), the promising internal structure is shown in Fig. 4d. The system is with a very uniform and solid microstructure, and almost no large voids can be identified. With the increasing nano-MgO content (20‰), there is some distortion for the microstructure of the stabilized soil (Fig. 4e). It can be seen that the agglomerates tend to decompose, indicating bond breakage. This implies that excessive amounts of nano-MgO in may cause excessive expansion and cracks (e.g. [23]).

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of sulfuric acid concentration
sections.text:
To investigate the influence of sulfuric acid concentration on the mechanical performance of nano-MgO and Cement-Admixed soil, the specimen was soaked in sulfuric acid solution with various concentrations (0.02 mol/L, 0.04 mol/L, 0.06 mol/L, and 0.08 mol/L). Visual observation in Fig. 5 clearly states that the surface of the specimen was damaged, which means structure loss due to the erosion of sulfuric acid. The erosion becomes more severe with higher sulfuric acid concentration. For the worst case with 0.08 mol/L sulfuric acid concentration, it can be seen that nearly one-third of the specimen was lost after the sulfuric acid attack. For the stress-strain characteristics (Fig. 6a), it reveals that the stress-strain curve is very steep for the specimen without sulfuric acid attack (i.e. sulfuric acid concentration = 0 mol/L). It shows that the stress-strain curve tends to be more and gentler
under higher sulfuric acid concentration, indicating lower stiffness of the specimen. And the UCS of specimen drops as the increase of sulfuric acid concentration (Fig. 6b). For the case with 0.08 mol/L sulfuric acid concentration, the UCS is only around 1/5 of that without sulfuric acid attack. This clearly states that the sulfuric acid attack will have more severe effects on the strength performance of cemented soil under higher sulfuric acid concentration.
In terms of the SEM images, it can be seen from Fig. 7a that when the specimen is soaked in clean water, the system is tight due to the formation of agglomerate without obvious porous structure identified. Some small granule unit is attached on the surface of agglomerate. Fig. 7b reveals that under the 0.02 mol/L sulfuric acid erosion, the dense structure of agglomerate is disrupted. And separated some large or small aggregates could be observed. This indicates the destruction of cementation bond. Once the concentration of sulfuric acid is increased to be 0.04 mol/L, it can be found from Fig. 7c that the aggregates demonstrate further separation, with worse connection with each other. And some of the rodshaped particles are formed at the same time. Overall, the system presents a porous structure, with some obvious large voids. With the increase of sulfuric acid concentration (0.06 or 0.08 mol/L), more disturbed and loose structure can be identified (Fig. 7d and e). While more rod-like and acicular units are generated. The acicular-shaped ettringite generated due to large amount of SO42 ion is also one reason for the structure distortion. This is because that ettringite will cause volume expansion, generating some micro-cracks or disturbing the microstructure.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The strength properties and microstructure of Nano-MgO admixed cemented soil was investigated in this study, while the effects of cement content, nano-MgO content and sulfuric acid concentration was examined. Experimental results show that UCS increases almost linearly within cement content from 7% to 13%, while the increment rate slows down from cement content of 13% to 17%. The nano-MgO content plays a significant role in the strength properties of the stabilized soil. For cement content of 13%, 15‰ nano-MgO content is the optimum scenario both without and under sulfuric acid attack condition. The addition of nano-MgO not only improves the UCS of the stabilized soil but also tends to increase the ductility of the stabilized soil. Microstructure analysis reveals that the addition of nano-MgO leads to a compacted structure, 15‰ nano-MgO content helps to generate a very uniform and solid microstructure. However, overuse of nano-MgO may generate cracks due to the excessive expansion. For the effect of sulfuric acid concentration, specimens under higher concentration solution will have lower strength and stiffness. This is due to structure loss caused by sulfuric acid erosion (outside) and structure distortion (inside) caused by ettringite generation, which is the possible mechanism of sulfuric acid attack.
Conflict of interest
The authors declare that there is no conflict of interest in this paper.

metadata.abstractText: The effectiveness of nano-MgO in strength properties and microstructure characteristics of cement stabilized soft soil were analyzed in this study. Sulfuric acid attack was also taken into account, and the effects nano-MgO content and sulfuric acid concentration were mainly addressed. Based on a series of unconfined compression tests, it shows that nano-MgO content plays a significant role in the strength properties of the stabilized soil. For the cement content of 13%, the optimum nano-MgO content is 15‰ considering both with and without sulphate attack condition. The addition of nano-MgO not only improves the unconfined compressive strength (UCS) of the cement stabilized soil, but also tends to increase its ductility. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) reveals that the addition of nano-MgO improves the microstructure of the stabilized soil, while overuse of nano-MgOmay generate cracks inside of the structure. For the effect of sulfuric acid concentration, specimens under higher concentration solution will have lower strength and stiffness. Finally, the mechanism of sulfuric acid attack on cemented soil was revealed to be outside structure loss caused by sulfuric acid erosion and inside structure distortion caused by ettringite generation. 2019 Elsevier Ltd.
